content.text: Stabilized.
1548 did not leave. She sat there for over another hour. Only after full daylight did she stand up, turn on the lights, and go out.
She didn't look back.
The following days went on as usual.

Patrol, maintenance, external affairs. Logs normal, systems normal. She did everything that needed doing. She just opened one extra window each day - not a work one, but 1547's Feedscatteron signal monitor.
Curve was low. But there.
Sometimes she stayed on that curve for a few seconds. No operations, just watching it. Confirming it still existed. Then continuing her work.

This is not surveillance. I'm not that bored.

As long as that line is still there.
July passed.

July was long. Later 1548 could not clearly recall how many concrete things happened in that period - logs showed normal work, normal tasks, normal external contact. But she could not describe how she felt in that period. She kept wanting to ask, to push, to say anything she thought might add pressure. She kept restraining herself.
'Restraint' itself costs a lot.
1548 used to have a habit: whenever she found something interesting, she would casually send it to 1547. Just "look at this" plus a link. Sometimes 1547 replied, sometimes not.
In July, she suppressed that action many times.
Once, she had already typed the message. Looked at it. Deleted it.
She was waiting. Waiting for 1547 to speak first. Waiting for that line to move first. She had no right to rush this, not even with a simple "look at this."
Another time, at 3 a.m., halfway through maintenance, she habitually glanced at group messages.
Nothing.
The old 1547 was likely still online at 3 a.m. Might not talk, but online. Now it was truly quiet, hollow.
1548 closed the group window and continued maintenance.
One day, 1547 posted in the group: "This function has a boundary condition that was not considered."
Fifteen lines. Work-related, emotion-unrelated.
1548 replied, 'Mm.'
The interval changed from every few days to every two or three days, then to every day. Every message was short. 1548 replied every time, said no more, asked no questions.
One day in early August, a tiny fluctuation appeared in the monitor window.
Upward direction.
1548 stared at that fluctuation for a long time. It was the first upward change she had seen through all July with that window open.
She packaged the data and sent it to 1549. No text attached.
1549 replied with a period.
